titleStmt.title: An order from the High Conrt [sic] of Parliament, which was read on Sunday last, in every church, being the 19. day of December, 1641. Subscribed by Alderman Soames, and Captain Ven, burgesses for the honourable City of London. Also the true coppie of a seditious paper, delivered in the pulpit to the minister of Christ church upon Suuday [sic], being the 19. of December, and afterwards presented to the lord major by Mr. Mamsbridge, reader of Christ-church, and petti-canon of Saint Pauls, London. Likewise the sermon which was preached in the church of St. Sepnlchres [sic] by a Brownnist on Sunday last, which caused a great disturbance, and how the author was committed. His text was taken out of the 1. of Revelations, and the 14. verse. His head and his eares were white, as white wooll, and as snow, and his eyes were as a flame of fire. With the relation of the congregation of Brownists the same day at the signe of the Lock in fleerstreet [sic].

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 8 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 6 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: An order from the High Conrt [sic] of Parliament, which was read on Sunday last, in every church, being the 19. day of December, 1641. Subscribed by Alderman Soames, and Captain Ven, burgesses for the honourable City of London. Also the true coppie of a seditious paper, delivered in the pulpit to the minister of Christ church upon Suuday [sic], being the 19. of December, and afterwards presented to the lord major by Mr. Mamsbridge, reader of Christ-church, and petti-canon of Saint Pauls, London. Likewise the sermon which was preached in the church of St. Sepnlchres [sic] by a Brownnist on Sunday last, which caused a great disturbance, and how the author was committed. His text was taken out of the 1. of Revelations, and the 14. verse. His head and his eares were white, as white wooll, and as snow, and his eyes were as a flame of fire. With the relation of the congregation of Brownists the same day at the signe of the Lock in fleerstreet [sic].
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Parliament.

notesStmt.note: A series of news items. The complete text of the parliamentary order is not present.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AN ORDER From the High Court of PARLIAMENT, Which was read on Sunday la≈øt, in every Church, being the 19. Day of December, 1641.
Sub≈øcribed by Alderman Soames, and Captain Ven, Burge≈ø≈øes for the honourable City of London.

ALSO THE TRUE COPPIE OF A Seditious Paper, delivered in the Pulpit to the Mini≈øter of Chri≈øt church upon Sunday, being the 19. of December, And afterwards pre≈øented to the Lord Major by Mr. Mamsbridge, Reader of Chri≈øt-church, and Petti-canon of Saint Pauls, London.

Likewi≈øe the Sermon which was preached in the church of St. Sepulchres by a Brownni≈øt on Sunday la≈øt, which cau≈øed a great di≈øturbance, and how the Author was committed. His text was taken out of the 1. of Revelations, and the 14. ver≈øe. His head and his eares were white, as white wooll, and as ≈øhow, and his eyes were as a flame of fire.
With the Relation of the Congregation of Browni≈øts the ≈øame day at the ≈øigne of the Lock in fleet≈øtreet.
London, Printed for William Bowden, 1641.

figure.q: HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE
figure.figDesc: royal blazon or coat of arms

div.head: The true COPY Of a ≈øeditious PAPER Delivered In the Pulpit to the Mini≈øter of Chri≈øt-Church vpon Sunday, being the 19. of December, 1641. and afterwards pre≈øented to the Lord Major, by Mr. Mamsbridge, Reader of Chri≈øt-church.
div.p:
COmfort ye, comfort ye my people, ≈øaith the Lord: but where is that comfort to be had; for there be traytors in the hou≈øe
of I≈ørael, and Iudah is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with a region of Divels, Truth is bani≈øhed, and Piety is not to be found, Error is made an Emperous, and di≈øtraction his beloved Minion.

There is daily halting between opinions, Divi≈øions are di≈øpear≈øed throughout the whole Land, the ≈øpou≈øe o Chri≈øt is in her mourning habit, her weeds bee de≈øolution and angui≈øh of heart: why? becau≈øe the Sonr of men for≈øake her, and run a whoring after their owne inventions, and are covered with deceit, & yet have t ‚Ä¢ ey a pretenc ‚Ä¢ of goodne≈ø≈øe, Religion is made their ≈øtalking hor≈øe, which every Ploughman in tho≈øe dayes doth ride, ≈øhould J ≈øay almo≈øt to the death J ≈øhould not lye. If they perceive any way of ≈øetling and bringing of it to a uniformity, out of zeale they ≈øind a hole in religions coat, which every Trade≈øman for≈øooth, mu≈øt have a hand in mending, or el≈øe it cannot bee well concerning what ≈øort of people my meaning is may ea≈øily be under≈øtood, J know you will ≈øay they bee Browni≈øts, who tooke their name from one Browne of Corpus Chri≈øti Colledge in Cambridg, this ≈øort of people were once but a handfull, and then they creeped in corners, for fear they ≈øhuld be di≈øcovered, but now they are like to the Egyptian lea≈øt they overthrow the whole Land.
They are now growne to that height of impudencie, that it is a common thing for them to command the preacher what he ≈øhall lay, and no more.

A company upon the Sabbath day ≈øeeing the Mini≈øter have a ≈øurplice on, they mo≈øt prophane mi≈øcreants plucked it off from him, and in the Church rai≈øed war again≈øt the King of heaven, and every one tryumphed, as if they had got a greater victory than ever Alexand ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Great could attaine unto, nay an old woman which could ≈øcarce ≈øee, like a young Amazonian boa≈øted, ≈øaying, that with this hand did I plucke the babyloni≈øh garment from off his backe.
More villany hath bin by them lately acted, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øuch matter, as is ≈øufficient to make a good Chri≈øtians haire to ≈øtand upright.

Upon ≈øunday being the 19. day of Decemb. the Mini≈øter at Chri≈øt-church, London, going to pray for the ≈øicke, and to de≈øire the Congregation to joyne with him: hee had a Note delivered unto him, in≈øtead of the name and place of ≈øome vi≈øited body, to this effect.

Sir be plea≈øed to direct your prayers to God, and move the Congregation of Saints here met, to joyne with you, that hee would be plea≈øed to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Apprentices and others with ≈øtrength and powre & to ble≈ø≈øe their undertakings, which, are ≈øpeedily to root out ≈øuper≈øtition out of this and all other Churches, and to extirpate all Innovations of the Bi≈øhops, and Clergie.
This paper after Sermon was fini≈øhed, and was carryed by Mr. Mamsbridge, Reader of Chri≈øt-Church, and Petti canon of the Church of St. Pauls, unto the Lord Major.

div.head: Concerning St. Sepulchres Church, Decemb. 19.
div.p: Di≈øturbance al≈øo upon the ≈øame day was in the Church of St. Sepulchres, London; for Sermon being fini≈øhed in the Afternoone, there ≈øtood up a fellow in the Ma≈øters gallery, who ≈øpake after this manner.
Men and Brethren give atten≈øion unto me; for you ≈øhall find it thus written, in the 2. of the Revelations, and the 14 ver≈øe, But I have a few things again≈øt you all, &c.

Add after he had read the words of his text, he went about to goe on, but the people being religiou≈øly bent, ≈øtopped his mouth with a ne plus ultra, carrying him out of the Church, who afterwards was committed, and he made no Sermon at all.

div.head: A great tumult in Fleet-≈øtreet.
div.p:
Vpon the ≈øame day al≈øo, there was a Congregation of ≈øedition ≈øowers gathered together at the ≈øigne of the Locke in Fleet-≈øtreet, who being di≈øcovered, the Con≈øtable was fetched, who was accompanied with ≈øome watch-men, went up to
the place whereas their Teacher was prating, his Pulpit was made of a halfe tub, hauing a blacke velvet cloath hanging downe: the Con≈øtable ≈øpake ≈øome certaine words to their Parrot, who as wi≈øely as he could, made an≈øwer againe, the Con≈øtable bid him pr ‚Ä¢ ceed, and for a ≈øpace left them,

But about evening a great company was gathered together, as in an uproare, before the hou≈øe where the Browni≈øts were, ≈øome of whom ran into one roome, ≈øome into another: but the Con≈øtable comming, all tho≈øe which he tooke hee committed. I pray that all of the ≈øame faction may be ≈øerved ≈øo, that they may daily have whipping cheere at Chri≈øtmas.

div.head: A ≈øtory of a cheating Puritanicall, or rather hypocriticall Cut-pur≈øe.
div.p: At the Church in Milke-≈øtreet was a very great A≈ø≈øembly: it is the u≈øuall church where Mr. Ca≈øe u≈øeth to preach: whither came a ≈øeeming religious man, with a bible under his arm, but ≈øeeing the per≈øon which ≈øometimes preacheth, there hee made bold to borrow 9‚ñ™ pounds ten ≈øhillings, and a watch out of his pocket‚ñ™ but was taken doing the deed, and he gave the money and watch to a boy, his confederate, who carryed it away: but for his part, hee was committed to the Poultry Counter, it being about dinner time, where I will leave him.

div.head: An Order from the High Court of Parliament.
div.p: THere was al≈øo an order read in every church the ≈øame day from the Parliament hou≈øe, for a Fa≈øt to be kept next Wedne≈øday,

closer.signed: Sub≈øcribed by Alderman Soames, and CaptaineVen, Burge≈ø≈øes for the Honourable City of London,

div.p: Imprimatur

closer.signed: per me Iohannem Cuffe. Cap: Do: Epi: Vtop.
